Many across the spectrum agree on strengthening prevention and support—better healthcare access, childcare, and workplace protections—so fewer pregnancies end in crisis. The remaining legal questions should be handled with clear standards that protect patients and clinicians in medical emergencies.

Abortion policy should be guided by the shared desire to protect vulnerable life while avoiding laws that create needless medical risk or criminalize desperate situations. A bridge is to invest heavily in preventing unintended pregnancy and in supporting parents, while setting any legal boundaries in a way that is medically workable and democratically accountable. This keeps the focus on reducing abortions through support, not punishment.

Laws on abortion should be guided by fairness and realism: people disagree about moral status, but most agree that women should not be endangered and children should be welcomed with adequate support. Common ground lies in prevention, strong social services, and clear health-based exceptions that doctors can apply without fear. Good law should make fewer families face this decision and make outcomes safer when they do.
